title: 'Trump is a dark horse': Russians on the invasion of Ukraine, three years on 27 minutes ago Steve Rosenberg Russia editor Reporting from Tver 'We want Ukraine's total capitulation'
body:
Driving into Tver, the first thing I notice are the soldiers.  They're everywhere. On billboards, the sides of buildings, at bus stops.
Portraits with the words "Hero of Russia". Posters of troops with Kalashnikov rifles encouraging the public to "Love, be proud of and defend" Russia.
  In other words, to sign up and go and fight in Ukraine. Three years after its full-scale invasion of its neighbour, Russia is seeking new recruits.
  Despite all the military imagery around town, if you live in Tver it's possible to convince yourself that life is normal. The front line is hundreds of miles away.
  "Just look around," Mikhail, a local teacher, tells me. "Cars are passing by and all the shops are open. No shells are falling from anywhere. We are not panicking. We can't hear any sirens wailing. We do not run to any evacuation points."
  For many Russians their invasion of Ukraine – what the Kremlin still calls a "special military operation" – is something they only encounter on their TV screens.
  But for people like Anna, it's much more real.
  "I know a lot of people who went off to fight," Anna says when we get chatting on the street.
  "Some of them never came home. I hope [the war] ends as soon as possible."
  Donald Trump claims that's what he wants, too. Without inviting Ukraine to the negotiating table, the Trump administration has already entered direct talks with the Russian leadership.
  What do Russians make of the US president and his overtures to Moscow?
  "Trump is a dark horse," believes Anna. "I'm not sure what to expect from him."
  Some of the people I talk to in Tver repeat the official narrative they have been hearing for the last three years on state TV: that their country is not the aggressor, that Russia is defending Russians and Russian-speakers in Ukraine and liberating, not occupying, territory.
  It doesn't mean that Russian society as a whole buys into this alternative reality.
  "In a society people always prefer to be in the mainstream," believes Andrei Kolesnikov, a columnist for newtimes.ru and Novaya Gazeta. "If the mainstream is pro-war and the TV says that we are at war with the West, the average citizen will think like this. It's easier not to think about the details. You want to live peacefully, so why not join the majority?
  "Some researchers call this the foetal position. When you defend yourself from this unexplainable world you look like a baby. You say: 'I can't explain to myself what is happening. I believe you. You can feed me with words. I'll accept it.' This is typical for all societies of this kind: a bit authoritarian, a bit totalitarian."
  Larissa and her husband Valery willingly accept the official line.
  "We're all for the special military operation," Larissa tells me. "We're ready to volunteer and go there ourselves!"
  They haven't yet, clearly.
  "We hope [Russia] will be victorious. We want Ukraine's total capitulation."
  The police turn up. They've received a call informing them that "suspicious-looking people with a camera" are going around Tver. Meaning us.
  They're polite but want to know why we're here. They take a statement from our driver. They check our vehicle. They ask me for an official explanation for our visit. I tell them we're gauging the mood away from Moscow. We show our documents, which are in order.
  While we've been talking to the officers, a camera crew from Russian state TV has pitched up and started filming us.
  "We were just passing," says the reporter, "and we spotted the police and recognised you. Can you tell me what's going on?"
  "I don't know," I reply. "Perhaps you can tell us?"
  "What have you been filming?"
  "We've been talking to people on the street," I say. "I believe we're allowed to do that."
  "Yes, in our country we have freedom of speech," the reporter replies. "Perhaps the police just want to help you? It's unpleasant to hear Western TV spreading fake news that there's no free speech in Russia. You're talking to people freely and no one gets in your way."
  "Apart from you," I point out. "And the police officers standing next to our car."
  The incident, which lasted about an hour, is no real surprise. Three years of war have fuelled suspicion of the West inside Russia. Early signs of a thaw in US-Russian relations have yet to change that.
  From talking to people in Tver it becomes clear that Russians are hoping that an end to the fighting will bring economic relief.
  "Prices are so high now for the things I need most," says Yulia as she rocks her baby to sleep in a pram. "Like the price of potatoes and onions. I really feel it."
  But teacher Mikhail doesn't feel that Donald Trump has any strategy for securing peace.
  "Unfortunately, Trump hasn't got any plan," believes Mikhail. "He is an improviser. He doesn't know what he's going to do. My sympathies are with him. I'm glad he won. But speaking about this episode, we're all in the dark. And Trump is in the dark himself."
  A Baltic Sea cable has been damaged for the third time in recent months, Finnish telecom operators say.
  Sir Nick Carter says "others are going to have to step up to the plate" if the US does not want to.
  A Ukrainian audience member on BBC Question Time describes her family being divided following Russia's full-scale invasion in 2022.
  The BBC's Analysis Editor Ros Atkins looks at why the US wants access to Ukraine's minerals.
  The US and Ukrainian Presidents clash after Trump initiates talks with Russia, excluding Ukraine.

political_party.name: Reform Party of the United States of America

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article references Donald Trump and discusses his actions, implying his role as the US President, but it does not explicitly state his title.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Donald Trump" and refers to him as the US president, indicating the target entity is present in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: Statements are attributed to him: "Donald Trump claims that's what he wants, too" and later remarks that "Trump hasn't got any plan" and "Donald Trump has any strategy for securing peace." These are clear attributions of opinion or claim to the individual.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q22686 (Donald Trump, President of the United States) matches the name, description, and current role. Candidate Q27947481 is a physician and does not fit the context. Thus Q22686 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the position of US President (2025–present), giving him the authority to make statements about foreign policy and negotiations with Russia.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is plausible for the US president to claim a desire for peace and to be involved in talks with Russian leadership, matching the article’s context.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity is present, making statements, and the best matching Wikidata entry is Q22686. All critical identification, authority, and plausibility criteria are satisfied.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article references Donald Trump and discusses his actions, implying his role as the US President, but it does not explicitly state his title.

position_held.name: Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly quotes "Sir Nick Carter", confirming the name and title, but provides no additional context to place him in a specific taxonomy category.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Sir Nick Carter" in the sentence: "Sir Nick Carter says 'others are going to have to step up to the plate' if the US does not want to." Thus the target entity is present in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: The same sentence attributes a direct statement to Sir Nick Carter, indicating that the entity is making a declarative comment.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Among the provided candidates, only Q7026864 (Nick Carter, British Army general) shares the name "Nick Carter" and a military background that could plausibly be associated with a knighthood (hence the title "Sir"). The other candidates (rapper, pop singer, basketball player, writer, tennis player) do not match the context or the title. Therefore Q7026864 is the best available match for the mentioned entity.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q7026864 held senior positions in the British Army (Chief of the Defence Staff, Chief of the General Staff). While the statement concerns US political actions, a high‑ranking military officer could comment on international security matters. No explicit evidence of a knighthood is present in the candidate data, but the title "Sir" in the article suggests the individual is knighted, which is plausible for a senior general.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is reasonable for a senior British Army general to make a public statement about the need for the US to act in the context of the Russia‑Ukraine conflict. The statement style and content are consistent with a military or security‑focused perspective, making attribution to Q7026864 plausible.
reasoning.final_justification: Sir Nick Carter is present in the article and is making a statement. The only candidate that reasonably matches the name, title, and military context is Q7026864. Despite the lack of explicit knighthood data, the title "Sir" and the general’s senior role support this attribution. Therefore, Q7026864 is selected as the best match for both presence and statement attribution.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly quotes "Sir Nick Carter", confirming the name and title, but provides no additional context to place him in a specific taxonomy category.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly quotes "Sir Nick Carter", confirming the name and title, but provides no additional context to place him in a specific taxonomy category.
